user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_GetResourceName:
```c
int32 OS_GetResourceName(osal_id_t object_id, char *buffer, size_t buffer_size)
{
    OS_common_record_t *record;
    int32               return_code;
    size_t              name_len;
    OS_object_token_t   token;

    /* sanity check the passed-in buffer and size */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(buffer);
    OS_CHECK_SIZE(buffer_size);

    /*
     * Initially set the output string to empty.
     * This avoids undefined behavior in case the function fails
     * and the caller does not check the return code.
     */
    buffer[0] = 0;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, OS_ObjectIdToType_Impl(object_id), object_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        record = OS_ObjectIdGlobalFromToken(&token);

        if (record->name_entry != NULL)
        {
            name_len = OS_strnlen(record->name_entry, buffer_size);
            if (buffer_size <= name_len)
            {
                /* indicates the name does not fit into supplied buffer */
                return_code = OS_ERR_NAME_TOO_LONG;
                name_len    = buffer_size - 1;
            }
            memcpy(buffer, record->name_entry, name_len);
            buffer[name_len] = 0;
        }

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_GetResourceName:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
#define OS_CHECK_SIZE(val) ARGCHECK((val)>0&&(val)<(UINT32_MAX/2),OS_ERR_INVALID_SIZE)
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
static inline osal_objtype_t OS_ObjectIdToType_Impl(osal_id_t id)
{
    return (OS_ObjectIdToInteger(id) >> OS_OBJECT_TYPE_SHIFT);
}
...
OS_common_record_t *OS_ObjectIdGlobalFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    uint32 base_idx = OS_GetBaseForObjectType(token->obj_type);
    return &OS_common_table[base_idx + token->obj_idx];
}
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef struct OS_common_record OS_common_record_t
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_ERR_NAME_TOO_LONG (-13)
...
static inline size_t OS_strnlen(const char *s, size_t maxlen)
{
    const char *end = (const char *)memchr(s, 0, maxlen);
    if (end != NULL)
    {
        /* actual length of string is difference */
        maxlen = end - s;
    }
    return maxlen;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no statically unreachable code fragments in the provided code. Rationale:

- There are no statements after an unconditional return or after an infinite loop within the shown functions. All return statements are terminal for their branch and do not leave dead code following them.

- Control flow in OS_GetResourceName is conditional but every statement (buffer[0] = 0; the success branch guarded by if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS); the inner name handling guarded by if (record->name_entry != NULL)) is reachable depending on runtime conditions; none are syntactically unreachable.

- The helper functions shown (OS_ObjectIdGetById, OS_ObjectIdGlobalFromToken, OS_strnlen, OS_ObjectIdRelease) likewise contain no clearly unreachable statements in the excerpts provided; their returns and conditionals are normal control-flow constructs.

- The only macros referenced (OS_CHECK_POINTER -> BUGCHECK and OS_CHECK_SIZE -> ARGCHECK) are not fully defined here. If those macros expand to non-returning constructs (for example, infinite loops or calls to noreturn functions), they could make subsequent code unreachable; however, no such non-returning semantics are present in the supplied definitions. Without a concrete definition that proves non-returning behavior, it would be speculative to mark code after those macros as unreachable. If the project’s BUGCHECK/ARGCHECK implementation is non-returning, that should be examined separately — but based on the provided definitions this cannot be concluded.

Given the provided code and symbol definitions, there are no definite unreachable code fragments to report. If you can supply the full definitions/expansions of BUGCHECK and ARGCHECK (or any other macro/utility that might be non-returning), I can re-check specifically for any code rendered unreachable by those implementations.
